entry.title: Re: Quantity Confirmation Beyond Tolerance Not Stopping i...
entry.content:
Hi,

Quantity Confirmation can be sensitive to checks flagged in OPK4, see Quantity Confirmation for some details.

Out of the box, Quantity Confirmation POD Plugin in Order POD does not prevent over confirmation at all, so if you have this as a requirement, I suggest you consider custom development/extension possibilities.

Br, Manoel

entry.title: Closing SAP FI AA - End Year - Process Public cloud
entry.content:
Dear community,

We have several entities (company codes) and would like to confirm the procedure for closing the AA module in advance.

Step by step:

1/Run the last depreciation jobs on 12/31/N.

2/Run the AA closing job via Schedule Fixed Asset Accounting Jobs.

3/Change the year (2024 to 2025 in the lower section) in ‚ÄúMake company code settings.‚Äù

Does this process seem correct to you?

Isn't it necessary to run the carryforward before these steps?

Thank you for your comments and for any precautions to take in case we want to reopen the period.

Regards,

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025: SPAIDER Revolucionando Procesos con Inteligencia Artificial
entry.content:
El SAP Inside Track Paraguay #SITCDE2025 nos regal√≥ una charla fascinante de la mano de Douglas Figueiredo, Socio y CTO de TEIA Connect, @Teia_Connect quien con m√°s de 18 a√±os de experiencia en proyectos SAP, nos present√≥ SPAIDER: una soluci√≥n que est√° revolucionando la manera en que las empresas interact√∫an con sus sistemas mediante inteligencia artificial



Douglas comparti√≥ una visi√≥n clara: la inteligencia artificial debe generar valor real en el mundo empresarial. SPAIDER se enfoca en empoderar al usuario final para que ejecute actividades repetitivas y complejas usando simplemente lenguaje natural.

"La persona m√°s importante en el sistema es el usuario final, y necesitamos darle autonom√≠a para que pueda hacer sus actividades utilizando los motores de inteligencia artificial."

¬øQu√© es SPAIDER?
SPAIDER (SAP Process Artificial Intelligence Evolution Resolution) es un asistente virtual que conecta usuarios con sistemas SAP. El nombre fusiona ingeniosamente Teia (telara√±a en portugu√©s) con Spider (ara√±a en ingl√©s), representando c√≥mo esta soluci√≥n conecta todos los elementos del ecosistema empresarial a trav√©s de un chat intuitivo.


Los Cuatro Pilares de SPAIDER
SPAIDER-eDOCS: Gestiona autom√°ticamente documentos fiscales electr√≥nicos, emitiendo m√°s de 30 tipos de documentos obligatorios, consultando XMLs y optimizando aprobaciones gubernamentales.
SPAIDER-MONI: Monitoreo inteligente que supervisa aspectos t√©cnicos y de negocio, alertando proactivamente sobre problemas antes de que impacten las operaciones.
SPAIDER-ESPEC: Genera especificaciones funcionales y prototipos mediante conversaci√≥n natural, permitiendo que cualquier usuario documente requisitos sin conocimientos t√©cnicos.
SPAIDER-TEST: Automatiza pruebas de regresi√≥n, ejecutando procesos completos y comparando valores con precisi√≥n del 100%. Genera evidencias en PDF para validaci√≥n de cambios.



Durante la presentaci√≥n, Douglas mostr√≥ el poder del lenguaje natural con SPAIDER-TEST. Con un simple comando como "crear un pedido de venta normal", el sistema identifica el tipo de pedido, consulta la referencia, crea autom√°ticamente todo el proceso (pedido, entrega, factura) y presenta los resultados de forma clara.
Cuando modific√≥ intencionalmente un dato de material para simular un impacto fiscal, SPAIDER-TEST detect√≥ autom√°ticamente las diferencias, las cuantific√≥ con precisi√≥n y gener√≥ un reporte comparativo. Todo esto sin escribir c√≥digo ni navegar por m√∫ltiples transacciones SAP.


La Visi√≥n de Teia Connect
Lo m√°s inspirador fue entender la filosof√≠a de Teia Connect sobre IA: no reemplazar personas, sino empoderarlas. En Teia, todos utilizan IA diariamente, los candidatos deben demostrar c√≥mo la usan, y cada producto se construye con esta tecnolog√≠a. Como Douglas enfatiz√≥: "La integraci√≥n debe ser transparente para el usuario, sin necesidad de mirar m√∫ltiples transacciones."
El Mensaje Final
SPAIDER representa un cambio fundamental en la interacci√≥n con sistemas empresariales: democratizar el acceso para que cualquier usuario ejecute procesos complejos, liberar tiempo estrat√©gico automatizando tareas repetitivas, y generar valor real usando IA para resolver problemas concretos de negocio.
¬øLo mejor? SPAIDER es modular y escalable, adapt√°ndose a las necesidades espec√≠ficas de cada empresa.

Un especial agradecimiento a Douglas Figueiredo por compartir su conocimiento y pasi√≥n por la innovaci√≥n, demostrando c√≥mo la inteligencia artificial puede transformar realmente los procesos empresariales. A Teia Connect por desarrollar soluciones que empoderan a los usuarios y generan valor tangible en el ecosistema SAP.

Gracias tambi√©n al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay por hacer posible estos espacios de aprendizaje que fortalecen nuestra comunidad y nos mantienen a la vanguardia de la tecnolog√≠a.

entry.title: Re: How to drop/delete attachment(s) from CPI message
entry.content:
The SAPNote 3240138 contains wrong code example. Correct syntax is (in time of my reply üòâ) :

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message def Message processData(Message message) { message.getAttachments().clear() message.getAttachmentWrapperObjects().clear() message.getAttachmentObjects().clear() return message }

entry.title: Everything My Mom Taught Me about Change Management for AI in Procurement
entry.content:
A Story about Change Done Right

Growing up, our dinner table conversations were a mix of stories about our day. My dad, a computer programmer for a large tech company, would talk about coding languages and mainframes, while my mom would share stories about her accounting role at a regional office for a global organization. Back then, I found myself leaning in whenever she talked about big changes happening at her office. 

What struck me, even as a kid, was a clear pattern: when changes were significant, her leadership team went above and beyond to make the office environment collaborative and supportive. They held town halls, brought in specialized trainers, and one memorable summer they even had an ice cream truck visit the office every Friday.  

I realize now that her leadership team understood something fundamental, which is that successful change management isn‚Äôt just about rolling out new tools, it‚Äôs about considering the human impact. My mom happily worked for that organization for years and even recruited me to intern there. That‚Äôs the power of thoughtful change management. 

So how can you model what my mom experienced when implementing AI in SAP Ariba or SAP Fieldglass? Let's look at the playbook. 

Clear Communications: Everyone Deserves to Know the ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù 

The first lesson from my mom's experience was transparency. Her leadership team didn't just announce changes, they explained the "why" behind their decisions and created multiple ways for employees to understand and engage.  

When you're implementing AI in procurement, develop a robust communication strategy that addresses where you're deploying it and the rationale behind those choices. Maybe you‚Äôre: 

  • Rolling out the AI-assisted SAP Ariba Category Management solution because it saves your team multiple hours per week by automating category analysis, enabling them to become strategic advisors with better data and faster identification of new business opportunities. 
  • Piloting intelligent resume analysis‚ÄØin SAP Fieldglass because it highlights top talent for hiring managers, giving them more time to focus on their core responsibilities while gaining a competitive advantage in talent acquisition. 

Be upfront about your reasoning. Use multiple communication channels that feel natural to your organization. Town halls work well for big-picture strategy and allowing open questions. "Ask Me Anything" sessions give employees a safe space to voice concerns. But don't stop there - weave updates into established channels like company newsletters, team meetings, and other standardized communications your teams already utilize and trust. 

Most importantly, identify and leverage internal champions early in your communication strategy. These trusted team members can help translate technical concepts into practical benefits and address concerns from their peers‚Äô perspective. When your teams have questions, take the time to answer them thoughtfully. This isn't just courtesy; it's essential for adoption. 

Special Training Programs: Don't Skip This Step 

Here‚Äôs where many organizations stumble. They want to skip comprehensive training and assume people will figure out AI-driven tools on their own. Don‚Äôt make this mistake. 

First, Get Your Data Foundation Right 

Before you can train effectively, you need clean data. AI works best when the underlying data is structured, reliable, and consistently maintained, but many procurement organizations struggle with data that‚Äôs scattered across systems. Supplier names often vary between purchase orders and contracts and spend categories don‚Äôt align across business units. This fragmentation creates obstacles to adoption. 

That‚Äôs why you need to start by explaining how AI works within your solutions. When a user sees an AI-generated recommendation in SAP Ariba or an AI-generated statement of work (SOW) description in SAP Fieldglass, they should understand which data inputs created that content and why it matters.  

Then, Focus on User Training  

  • With Joule, show users how conversational AI accesses your organization‚Äôs information and best practices, demonstrating why instant access to critical data improves their decision-making capabilities 
  • With SAP Ariba, help users understand how market and historical data analysis creates real-time category strategy, supplier insights, and RFP recommendations, enabling them to make confident decisions and respond faster to changing conditions  
  • With SAP Fieldglass, explain how basic project inputs generate comprehensive descriptions for both job descriptions and SOWs, so hiring managers can trust AI-enhanced deliverables while focusing on strategic workforce planning 

Finally, Nurture and Support your Champions 

Your champions will help drive your success and should also be involved in validating AI recommendations during pilot phases. When they can vouch for the accuracy and usefulness of AI-generated insights, your solutions will be more impactful and their endorsement will carry a lot of weight, just like my mom‚Äôs feedback did at her organization. Keep your champions engaged by recognizing their contributions publicly, providing them with exclusive previews of new features, and regularly asking them for their input on product improvements. Personalized attention helps maintain their enthusiasm and advocacy.  

Your team won't automatically love new features just because they're AI-driven. You need to train them properly, communicate quick wins clearly, and continuously drive adoption.   

Ice Cream for Everyone: The Human Element Matters 

That summer, my mom made it her mission to try every flavor from that ice cream truck. She‚Äôd come home excited to tell us about both the ice cream and the wins, big and small, that her team was racking up with their new processes. And the best part? The changes let her spend more time digging into the more interesting, complex invoices instead of processing the easy ones that were never flagged.   

The small gestures mattered as much as the robust communication plans and training programs, creating an environment where change felt celebratory rather than threatening. 

Don't underestimate the human element that comes with any significant change. While AI-enabled solutions like SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass ensure there's always a human in the loop, people still feel natural apprehension about adopting tools that are designed to drive efficiency. They wonder if their expertise will still be valued, if their jobs will change, or if they'll be able to master new ways of working.  

Address this directly by highlighting how AI creates opportunities for greater visibility and strategic impact. For example:   

  • Joule eliminates information bottlenecks‚ÄØby making information conversationally accessible. It puts details like purchasing insights and hiring best practices at users‚Äô fingertips. 
  • Sourcing and Bid Analysis Agents‚ÄØin SAP Ariba solutions reduce decision-making stress and increase agility by analyzing market and historical data to create and adapt RFPs in real time. This gives users confidence in purchasing decisions and faster responses to supply chain disruptions while freeing them to focus on negotiations and relationship building. 
  • The SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management solution elevates user roles by automating invoice processing where key thresholds are met. This reduces manual data entry so teams can focus on high-value exception management and build stronger vendor relationships. 
  • AI-assisted SOW creation tools in SAP Fieldglass applications streamline project planning by generating comprehensive descriptions from basic project inputs, enabling hiring managers to create detailed SOWs faster. The tools also drive consistency across templates and projects, which helps users shift from administrative workforce management to strategic talent optimization. 

The key is showing employees that AI elevates their expertise rather than replacing it, much like how my mom's new systems and processes made her work more strategic and less manual.  

Change Management Best Practices Actually Work 

Successful AI adoption follows the same change management approach that worked for my mom's organization years ago: clear communication, comprehensive training, genuine support, and celebration of progress. It‚Äôs a timeless template for transformation. 

  • Communicate clearly and frequently about what's changing and why. 
  • Invest in comprehensive training that's tailored for all skill levels. 
  • Create‚ÄØopportunities for feedback and iteration. 
  • Acknowledge that change is challenging and provide support.   

Most importantly, keep the human experience at the center of your implementation strategy. Technology should make people's work more interesting and valuable, not more complicated or uncertain.   

When procurement professionals can spend less time on data compilation and more time on strategic initiatives, have better insights to inform negotiations, and respond more quickly to business needs ‚Äî that's when AI becomes fun and transformational.  

By getting this right, you ensure that your teams won't just adopt AI, they'll become advocates for it. They‚Äôll share success stories and help scale the transformation across your organization, and they'll talk about how much fun they‚Äôre having at the dinner table, just like my mom did.  

Ready to optimize your company's approach to AI? Check out the AI-based solutions that are already embedded in your SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass applications on our SAP Business AI for procurement webpage.

entry.title: Re: Operators available in Regular Expressions (RegEx) in...
entry.content:
Hello marek_s,

As per your communication with SAP via a logged case, currently there is only support for a limited subset of the POSIX regular expression flavor to be used in ABSL, hence the regEx expression you have done will not fully work in C4C.

You can refer to what regular expressions are supported in C4C with below documentation:
https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_752_index_htm/7.52/en-US/index.htm?file=abenregex_syntax.htm

Kind regards,
Thiago

entry.title: Re: Getting Error while opening solution in PRD
entry.content:
Hello Wasif_Hassan,

Another solution for this is to close the implementation manager at the time you have this error. Once implementation manager is closed, you can log off and close the SDK.

Next time you open SDK, the implementation manager should be closed and the error will not come up when you login.

Kind regards,
Thiago

Product : ABC.

Batch : 100 - Qty 25

Batch : 101 - Qty 25.

Sales Orders : ABC - 26.

=> At the outbound delivery creation,  the batch 100 is picked with the quantity of 26 instead of 25 plus 1 for the batch 101.

entry.title: Re: SolMan 7.2 RFC unable to set to confirmed in producti...
entry.content:
The following comes from a document I created for my own use, are provided ‚Äúas is‚Äù, with no claim of suitability to other customers‚Äô situations. Solution Manager 7.2, ST support pack 18, was used as a reference. YMMV

The steps describe a new entry. The reader should be able to select and edit an existing entry rather than creating a new entry.

Navigation

/nSPRO > SAP Reference IMG

> SAP Solution Manager Implementation Guide

> SAP Solution Manager

> Capabilities (Optional)

> Change Control Management

> Change Request Management Framework

Make Settings for Change Transaction Types

 

Specify Required Status Values for Follow-Up Documents

Use this procedure to ‚Äúdefine the statuses that follow-up documents (successor transactions) must have before a specific user status can be set for the current document.

‚ÄúFor the follow-up documents, Change Request Management action SET_PREDOC must be defined for this status so that the user status of the follow-up document can be set.‚Äù

[The above quoted text is from the SAP Reference IMG built-in documentation.]

For example, before an RFC can be set to Implemented, all related change documents (i.e., successor or follow-up documents) must be Completed or Withdrawn.

  1. In the Dialog Structure, select Create Transaction Types
    1. From the list, select the transaction type (of the predecessor document)
  2. In the Dialog Structure, select Specify Status Attributes
    1. From the list, select the User Status value (of the predecessor document)
      (hint: use the search help to view the status description)
  3. In the Dialog Structure, select Specify Required Status Values for Follow-Up Docs
  4. Select New Entry and enter the appropriate values:
    1. Transaction Type: Select the predecessor transaction type (document)
    2. Status Profile: Select the Status Profile
    3. User Status: Select the status value to which the predecessor transaction should be set.
    4. Select Save (select/create a transport request)
  5. Repeat to create new entries for all successor documents and statuses.

entry.content:
Dear community,

within the project to implement S/4 Hana On Premise, we would like to create different project profiles for WBS, as internal orders are not part of SAP's strategic anymore. Two of those profiles use custom fields which will be too complex to use the customizing functionality for that.

One kind of project had already been created in our ECC system using enhancement CNEX0007 and we're not sure yet if the complexity of these fields could also be reached using the custom fields fiori app. 

Now we're facing the challenge that we would like to use different user fields depending on the project profile. I have learned that field created by the enhancement and fields created by the custom fields app automatically go to different subscreens. However, neither of them appear in the "define field selection" customizing.

Now I'd like to find out if we could use the same approach for all fields but still display them on separate screens. I guess that the customizing transaction "Include User Defined Detail Screens" could help us there, but I don't know how to create such a screen to assign it. The fields assigned with the enhancement CNEX0007  automatically go to screen 1215 and I don't see where this would be defined.

I'd appreciate any help in this matter.

Thanks and regards

Yasmin

entry.title: Consuming the Free Open-Meteo Weather API Using ABAP ‚Äì A Practical, Reusable OOP Approach
entry.content:
In many SAP teams, external API integration is still considered complex or ‚Äúsomething middleware should handle‚Äù. But in reality, modern ABAP makes this easier than ever ‚Äî especially when we take a clean OOP approach.

To demonstrate this, I built a simple, real-world example using the Open-Meteo weather API.
It‚Äôs absolutely free, requires no authentication, and returns clean JSON.

Example call:

Free Open-Meteo Weather API 

This makes it a perfect learning API for ABAP developers who want to practice:

  • HTTP calls

  • JSON parsing

  • OOP design patterns

  • Storing data into SAP tables

  • Clean, reusable architecture

In this article, I walk through the exact steps to build a production-friendly ABAP solution that reads weather data and stores it in a Z-table ‚Äî using patterns that you can apply for ANY external REST API.

1. Business Use Case

You want to collect weather snapshots for specific locations, such as:

  • Seaport / airport operations

  • Logistics planning

  • Production environment monitoring

  • Shift planning during heavy rain conditions

  • Agricultural or outdoor operations

The Open-Meteo API provides:

  • Temperature

  • Windspeed

  • Wind direction

  • Weather code

  • Day/Night indicator

  • Timestamp

Our goal:

‚úî Call Open-Meteo
‚úî Parse JSON
‚úî Map data into an ABAP structure
‚úî Save a snapshot in a Z-table
‚úî Use clean OOP architecture

2. Create Z-Table to Store Weather Data

Table: ZWEATHER_SNAP

Suggested fields:

Field Description

LOCATION_IDLogical location name
OBS_DATEDate from API
OBS_TIMETime from API
LATITUDE / LONGITUDECoordinates
TEMP_CTemperature
WINDSPEEDkm/h
WINDDIRwind direction (degrees)
WEATHERCODEAPI weather code
IS_DAYX / blank
CREATED_ON / CREATED_AT / CREATED_BYTechnical audit

Sample DDL:

@EndUserText.label: 'Weather snapshot from Open-Meteo'
define table zweather_snap {
  key mandt        : abap.clnt;
  key location_id  : abap.char(20);
  key obs_date     : abap.dats;
  key obs_time     : abap.tims;

  latitude         : abap.dec(8,5);
  longitude        : abap.dec(8,5);
  timezone         : abap.char(40);
  temp_c           : abap.dec(5,2);
  windspeed        : abap.dec(5,2);
  winddir          : abap.dec(5,1);
  weathercode      : abap.int4;
  is_day           : abap.char(1);

  created_on       : abap.dats;
  created_at       : abap.tims;
  created_by       : abap.uname;
}

3. Define ABAP Types for JSON Mapping

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_current_weather,
         temperature   TYPE decfloat16,
         windspeed     TYPE decfloat16,
         winddirection TYPE decfloat16,
         weathercode   TYPE i,
         is_day        TYPE abap_bool,
         time          TYPE string,
       END OF ty_current_weather.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_api_response,
         latitude               TYPE decfloat16,
         longitude              TYPE decfloat16,
         timezone               TYPE string,
         current_weather        TYPE ty_current_weather,
       END OF ty_api_response.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_weather_snapshot,
         location_id TYPE zweather_snap-location_id,
         obs_date    TYPE dats,
         obs_time    TYPE tims,
         latitude    TYPE zweather_snap-latitude,
         longitude   TYPE zweather_snap-longitude,
         timezone    TYPE zweather_snap-timezone,
         temp_c      TYPE zweather_snap-temp_c,
         windspeed   TYPE zweather_snap-windspeed,
         winddir     TYPE zweather_snap-winddir,
         weathercode TYPE zweather_snap-weathercode,
         is_day      TYPE zweather_snap-is_day,
       END OF ty_weather_snapshot.

4. Provider Interface (Strategy Pattern)

INTERFACE zif_weather_provider PUBLIC.
  METHODS get_current_weather
    IMPORTING
      iv_latitude  TYPE decfloat16
      iv_longitude TYPE decfloat16
      iv_location  TYPE zweather_snap-location_id
    RETURNING VALUE(rs_weather) TYPE ty_weather_snapshot
    RAISING cx_root.
ENDINTERFACE.

This makes the design future-proof:
Tomorrow you can add other weather providers or internal REST services.

5. HTTP Authentication Helper (For Future APIs)

Open-Meteo does not require auth ‚Äî but real APIs usually do.
This helper makes your next extension very easy.

CLASS zcl_http_auth_helper DEFINITION PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PRIVATE.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS set_basic_auth
      IMPORTING io_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client
                iv_username TYPE string
                iv_password TYPE string.

    CLASS-METHODS set_bearer_auth
      IMPORTING io_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client
                iv_token TYPE string.
ENDCLASS.

6. Provider Class ‚Äî Calling Open-Meteo

CLASS zcl_weather_open_meteo DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES zif_weather_provider.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    CONSTANTS gc_base TYPE string VALUE
      'https://api.open-meteo.com/v1/forecast'.

    METHODS build_url
      IMPORTING iv_latitude  TYPE decfloat16
                iv_longitude TYPE decfloat16
      RETURNING VALUE(rv_url) TYPE string.

    METHODS map_api_to_snapshot
      IMPORTING is_api TYPE ty_api_response
                iv_location TYPE zweather_snap-location_id
      RETURNING VALUE(rs_snap) TYPE ty_weather_snapshot.
ENDCLASS.

Provider Implementation

CLASS zcl_weather_open_meteo IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD zif_weather_provider~get_current_weather.
    DATA lo_http TYPE REF TO if_http_client.
    DATA lv_url TYPE string.
    DATA lv_json TYPE string.
    DATA ls_api TYPE ty_api_response.

    lv_url = build_url( iv_latitude = iv_latitude
                        iv_longitude = iv_longitude ).

    cl_http_client=>create_by_url(
      EXPORTING url = lv_url
      IMPORTING client = lo_http ).

    lo_http->request->set_method( 'GET' ).

    lo_http->send( ).
    lo_http->receive( ).

    lv_json = lo_http->response->get_cdata( ).

    /ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(
      EXPORTING json = lv_json
      CHANGING  data = ls_api ).

    rs_weather = map_api_to_snapshot(
                    is_api = ls_api
                    iv_location = iv_location ).
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD build_url.
    rv_url = |{ gc_base }?latitude={ iv_latitude }| &&
             |&longitude={ iv_longitude }| &&
             |&current_weather=true|.
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD map_api_to_snapshot.
    DATA lv_date TYPE string.
    DATA lv_time TYPE string.

    SPLIT is_api-current_weather-time AT 'T'
      INTO lv_date lv_time.

    REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '-' IN lv_date WITH ''.
    REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF ':' IN lv_time WITH ''.
    CONCATENATE lv_time '00' INTO lv_time.

    rs_snap-location_id = iv_location.
    rs_snap-latitude    = is_api-latitude.
    rs_snap-longitude   = is_api-longitude.
    rs_snap-timezone    = is_api-timezone.
    rs_snap-temp_c      = is_api-current_weather-temperature.
    rs_snap-windspeed   = is_api-current_weather-windspeed.
    rs_snap-winddir     = is_api-current_weather-winddirection.
    rs_snap-weathercode = is_api-current_weather-weathercode.
    rs_snap-is_day      = COND #( WHEN is_api-current_weather-is_day = abap_true THEN 'X' ELSE space ).

    rs_snap-obs_date = lv_date.
    rs_snap-obs_time = lv_time.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

7. Repository Class ‚Äî Save to DB

CLASS zcl_weather_repository DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    METHODS save_snapshot
      IMPORTING is_snapshot TYPE ty_weather_snapshot.
ENDCLASS.

Implementation:

CLASS zcl_weather_repository IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD save_snapshot.
    DATA ls TYPE zweather_snap.
    MOVE-CORRESPONDING is_snapshot TO ls.

    ls-mandt      = sy-mandt.
    ls-created_on = sy-datum.
    ls-created_at = sy-uzeit.
    ls-created_by = sy-uname.

    INSERT zweather_snap FROM ls.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      MODIFY zweather_snap FROM ls.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

8. Application Service ‚Äî Business Orchestration

CLASS zcl_weather_app_service DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    METHODS constructor
      IMPORTING io_provider TYPE REF TO zif_weather_provider
                io_repo     TYPE REF TO zcl_weather_repository.

    METHODS collect_and_save
      IMPORTING iv_latitude TYPE decfloat16
                iv_longitude TYPE decfloat16
                iv_location TYPE zweather_snap-location_id.
ENDCLASS.

Implementation:

CLASS zcl_weather_app_service IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD constructor.
    me->io_provider = io_provider.
    me->io_repo = io_repo.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD collect_and_save.
    DATA ls TYPE ty_weather_snapshot.

    ls = io_provider->get_current_weather(
      iv_latitude  = iv_latitude
      iv_longitude = iv_longitude
      iv_location  = iv_location ).

    io_repo->save_snapshot( ls ).
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

9. Executable Report

REPORT zweather_collector.

PARAMETERS:
  p_lat TYPE decfloat16 DEFAULT '6.9271' OBLIGATORY,
  p_lon TYPE decfloat16 DEFAULT '79.8612' OBLIGATORY,
  p_loc TYPE zweather_snap-location_id DEFAULT 'COLOMBO' OBLIGATORY.

DATA lo_service TYPE REF TO zcl_weather_app_service.

START-OF-SELECTION.

  lo_service = NEW zcl_weather_app_service(
                 io_provider = NEW zcl_weather_open_meteo( )
                 io_repo     = NEW zcl_weather_repository( ) ).

  TRY.
      lo_service->collect_and_save(
        iv_latitude  = p_lat
        iv_longitude = p_lon
        iv_location  = p_loc ).
      WRITE: / 'Weather snapshot saved for', p_loc.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx).
      WRITE lx->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

10. Why This Pattern Is Better Than a One-Report Solution

‚úî Clean separation of concerns

  • Provider ‚Üí HTTP & JSON

  • Service ‚Üí Business logic

  • Repository ‚Üí DB operations

‚úî Highly reusable

You can connect ANY API by creating a new provider.

‚úî Future-proof for SAP BTP / ABAP Cloud

This layered design aligns with RAP & clean architecture.

‚úî Easy to maintain

Each class is small and focuses on one task.

‚úî Ready for automated jobs

You can run this via SM36 as a weather-collector batch job.

‚úî Perfect teaching material

Developers learn clean OOP practices with a simple, real API.

11. Where You Can Extend This

  • Build a Fiori List Report to display weather history

  • Publish weather snapshots via an OData V4 service

  • Add multiple locations

  • Add token authentication for your next article

  • Add job scheduling every 30 minutes

  • Add charts using CDS Analytical Queries

12. Final Thoughts

This small Open-Meteo exercise demonstrates how modern ABAP can easily consume external REST APIs using clean OOP architecture.

More importantly, this pattern applies to any scenario:

  • IoT sensor readings

  • Machine temperature & vibration

  • Traffic or route optimization APIs

  • Currency exchange APIs

  • Cloud microservices

  • Internal REST systems

Once you build this pattern once, you can reuse it across your entire SAP landscape.

entry.title: Re: PO delivery time with icoterm
entry.content:
Hi , 

I understand your point. 

There is no separate transit time (from vendor to your plant). Assuming the planned lead time includes shipping time by the vendor in other INCO term cases, here in your case there is no shipping time. Technically, you are taking ownership of goods at vendor's location and hence your GR processing time starts here. 

If you do not want to do above, some organizations do not really post GR at this point of time and use 2 work arounds :

1. Use 103 (receipt at vendor) & 101 (receipt at plant) movement types

2. Use Inbound Delivery (receipt at vendor) & 101 (receipt at plant 

In both the above cases, you need to include transit time in planned dely time. 

If you want to report transit time, you need to develop a report depending on which work around you used. 

Best regards, Ramki

entry.title: Re: PO not getting creating error EXPRESS DOCUMENT "UPDAT...

entry.title: Re: MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM - doesnt work - SAP Public C...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM does not influence the logic during Purchase Requisition (PR) ‚Üí Purchase Order (PO) conversion.
As a result, the ‚ÄúInfo Record Update‚Äù field remains empty when creating POs from PRs, even though it works correctly for manually created POs.

This is because PR-to-PO processing uses a different business context, and the BAdI you used is not called during this conversion step.

Root Cause

The PR-to-PO process runs in a controlled workflow where MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM is bypassed.
Therefore, any custom logic implemented in this BAdI will not be executed during PR conversion, which is why the Info Record Update flag is not defaulted automatically.

Resolution Overview

To ensure consistent behavior, you need to use the BAdI that is actually triggered for all PO creation modes‚Äîincluding conversions from PRs.

The correct BAdI for this scenario in Public Cloud is:

BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO

This BAdI is executed just before the PO is saved, making it reliable across manual creation, PR conversion, and automated processes.

The issue is caused by using a BAdI that does not participate in the PR-to-PO process.
Switching to BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO provides a reliable, Public Cloud‚Äìcompliant solution that ensures the ‚ÄúInfo Record Update‚Äù field is always set during all types of PO creation.

 

Extensibility for Purchase Order Apps

Best Regards'

Aishwarya

entry.title: Re: Adding where condition in CDS extension
entry.content:
Good day @dhina_007 

Thank you for your question.

Due to the public cloud clean-core principle, you cannot add a WHERE condition to a standard CDS view when you use CDS extensions. The reason is, adding WHERE changes the released API view and can potentially break dependent applications,  therefore violating the clean-core restrictions.

I recommend you create your own Custom CDS View (or Custom Analytical Query) based on the standard view and apply your required filters there.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Custom CDS Views, Extensibility Enablement, SAP HANA Core Data Services (CDS) Reference,

The Blog: Getting Started with ABAP Core Data Services (CDS)  also provides some good insights. Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Engineering Change Record (ECR) for Inspection Plan -...
entry.content:
Good day @ksnv 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Creating Change Record Types, Creating a Change Record & Manage Change Records

The public cloud, in its out-of-the box standard, currently does not support the inspection plan object type for change records. This restriction is also listed in the 3331841 Note under the limitations for Change Record types.

You can consult Note 3325248 for information on enabling Change Number for Dynamic Field Control in a Change Record.

Since the public cloud restricts the aforementioned point, here is what I suggest on how you can still achieve your goal:

  • Use ECR for supported objects such as Material, BOM and Document.
  • Manage Inspection Plan changes separately through workflow or documented governance
  • If you strictly require auditability, I suggest you build a BTP extension.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Provisioning source of a PR created from a service or...
entry.content:
Good day @PASEK 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Purchase Requisition, Account Assignment in Purchase Requisition,  Read a Purchase Requisition, Operations for Purchase Requisition, Custom Logic

In summary, the public cloud, due to its clean-core principle, does not provide the possibility to create PR from services orders through the enhancement of BAdIs. That means there is no BAdI to help you achieve your goal of changing the provisioning source of a PR requisition you created from a service order.  The provisioning source is determined strictly by the Material Master procurement type and the Service Order Item Category configuration.

If your intention is to automate, you can achieve this by modifying the PR after you have created using BTP and the API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV.

Let me know if you have further questions.



Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue: 0-Stock Materials Are Not Showing in Stock-Mul...
entry.content:
Hello @Ayuwan1212121212 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

The stock reports only display materials that have a physical stock record. The public cloud does not display stocks that have no quantity. There are a few options you can consider.

The simplest is to use Material Document List to show the material even if your stock is zero. As long as it has any movement, it will display it.

Here you can see different document types displayed. Which indicates materials that have been moved.

For option 2, you can also resolve that issue in public cloud by creating a custom CDS view combining Product Master and Materials Stock. This allows you to report on all materials, whether stock exist or not.

Let me know if you have further question on the CDS views creation.



Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Case Management: Case Hierarchy (Main Cases and Sub-Cases)
entry.content:
Introduction:

In modern case management systems, efficient organization of information is essential for delivering fast and accurate resolutions. Businesses today deal with increasingly complex service requests, operational tasks, and customer interactions. To manage this complexity, leading organizations rely on a hierarchical case structure consisting of main cases and sub-cases. This model provides clarity, accountability, and scalability, enabling teams to divide work intelligently without losing the connection to the bigger picture. With a clear case hierarchy, companies can accelerate issue resolution, improve customer satisfaction, and create a more predictable service operation.

Imagine a customer reports a serious issue that touches multiple departments‚Äîsupport needs to investigate, field service must schedule a visit, and billing has to verify an error. Handling everything under one case would quickly become messy. That‚Äôs where case hierarchy shines. A main case captures the overall problem, while sub-cases help each team manage their part of the work independently, yet still stay tied to the larger story.

Configuration:

In SAP Service Cloud v2, Case Hierarchy is offered as a separate feature that customers can enable at the case-type level. It also provides flexibility, allowing configuration changes across different case-type versions. At any given time, only one version of a case type can be active.

1. Open a draft case type version in detail view

 2. In the General tab, activate the Case Hierarchy feature within the Features Settings section. Once enabled, the Case Hierarchy functionality becomes available for that specific case type.

 3. After enabling the feature, a new tab called Relationship Settings becomes available. Navigate to this tab to proceed.

 4. Select a cascade completion mechanism for main and subcases. There are three options available for the completion mechanism. The first is None, where the main case and sub-cases can be completed independently. The second option, Don't allow main case completion until all sub-cases are completed, prevents closure of the main case until its sub-cases are finished. The third option, Complete all sub-cases when the main case is completed, automatically closes all sub-cases when the main case is completed. These options are largely self-explanatory.

5. Select the appropriate options based on your requirements, then click Save to apply the changes.

6. Click Activate to activate the case type.

Case Hierarchy in Action:

Hiring a Candidate in an Enterprise Service Management Scenario: Consider the process of hiring a new candidate‚Äîa common enterprise workflow that requires coordination across several internal departments. Although it begins as a single request, the end-to-end hiring process consists of multiple activities handled by different teams. This makes it an ideal scenario for using Case Hierarchy with a main case and multiple sub-cases.

When a hiring request is submitted, a main case is created to represent the overall process: onboarding a new employee. This main case captures the core details such as candidate information, job role, joining date, and overall status.

However, completing this process requires contributions from multiple departments: 

1. IT Department ‚Äî IT Setup Sub-Case

The IT team needs to prepare all the necessary resources for the new hire. A sub-case is created to handle tasks such as Laptop allocation and configuration, Email account and system access creation, Software license provisioning and Setting up workstation or remote access. This sub-case is managed independently by IT but remains linked to the main hiring case.

2. Finance Department ‚Äî Payroll & Compliance Sub-Case

Finance also plays a crucial role in onboarding. Their sub-case may include: Setting up payroll for the new employee, Assigning cost centers or budgeting codes, Compliance checks for compensation and benefits and Approvals related to financial onboarding. Again, these tasks are handled within the Finance sub-case but contribute to completing the overall hiring process.

3. HR Department ‚Äî HR Onboarding Sub-Case

The HR team completes several onboarding formalities, such as: Gathering and validating documents, Generating the offer letter and appointment contract, Assigning training, onboarding programs, and buddy systems, Ensuring background checks are completed and Capturing employee master data in the HR system. All of these actions are tracked in a dedicated HR sub-case.

Let‚Äôs create a case to demonstrate this scenario.

1. Create a new case with the newly activated case type and open the case in detail view.

2. To create a sub-case, click the Create button and select Sub-Case.

 3. Once the sub-cases are created, review them in the Sub-Cases section under the Related Entities tab. This tab and section are adaptation-relevant, so they must be added to the screen through Adaptation if they are not already visible.

 4. The Sub-Cases section also allows you to link an existing case as a sub-case. Click the Add Subcases button and choose the appropriate case from the value help and click on Apply.

Here, you can enter a search term, press Enter, and then select the desired case from the list.

Alternatively, click the value help icon to open the case list modal and choose the required case.

Click Apply to link the selected case as a sub-case.

It will then be displayed instantly in the related entities sub-cases section.

Use the Full Screen button to enlarge the section for better viewing.

Hover over the case card to reveal the Remove button, then click it to delink the sub-case.

For the current case type version, the completion mechanism ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt allow main case completion until all sub-cases are completed‚Äù is selected. This prevents the main case from being completed until all its sub-cases are resolved. If attempted to complete the main case before completing the sub-cases, a validation message is displayed.

The system will enforce the configured completion mechanism accordingly.

The hierarchy supports only one level, meaning a parent case can have sub-cases, but a sub-case cannot have its own sub-cases.

Summary:

Case Hierarchy in modern case management systems provides a structured way to manage complex processes by linking a main case with one or more sub-cases. This approach enables organizations to break down large tasks into manageable units while maintaining visibility and control over the overall workflow.

Key points:

  • Feature Enablement: In SAP Service Cloud v2, Case Hierarchy is a separate feature that must be enabled at the case-type level and can be configured differently across case-type versions. At any given time, only one version of a case type can be active.

  • Hierarchy Structure: A main case can have multiple sub-cases, but sub-cases cannot have further child cases, supporting a single-level hierarchy.

  • Completion Mechanism: The system supports configurable completion rules, such as allowing independent closure of main and sub-cases, preventing main case completion until sub-cases are finished, or automatically completing all sub-cases when the main case is closed.

  • Operational Flow: Sub-cases can be created directly or linked from existing cases. Departments like HR, IT, Finance, Facilities, Security, and, if relevant, Travel Desk (for relocations) typically manage the sub-cases, each handling specialized tasks while contributing to the main case‚Äôs resolution.

  • Benefits: Case Hierarchy enhances collaboration across departments, ensures accountability, improves tracking, and provides a clear view of progress at both sub-case and main case levels.

In essence, Case Hierarchy simplifies complex business processes by structuring work into related cases, ensuring that each task is efficiently tracked and managed while maintaining alignment with the overall objective.

entry.title: Custom PO Header & Item Text in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
We need to define and configure custom Purchase Order (PO) Header Text and Item Text.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Custom PO Header & Item Text in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi,

  • In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, PO header and item text types are pre-delivered and cannot be extended.

  • The system does not support adding new text types or modifying the standard text schema for purchasing documents.

  • This behavior is system standard for S/4HANA Public Cloud.

  • For additional custom fields, use Custom Fields and Logic app:

    • Create a custom field

    • Assign it to the Purchase Order Header or Item business context

    • Enable it in the UI (Manage Purchase Orders)

    • Include it in output forms if required

  • Custom fields appear as separate fields, not inside the classic ‚ÄúTexts‚Äù tab.

In case your request is critical for your Go Live, please reach out to your assigned Product Expert or Customer Engagement Executive who will help to coordinate your request. SAP offers a recently launched a new opportunity for SAP S/4HANA Cloud customers to submit improvement requests.

1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

2. Register and accept the Terms of Use

3. Choose a session of your interest

4. Create and submit your improvement request

5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

 

Best regards,

SAP Support
